ALLEGATION:
Staff left medical isolation and suicidal youth unattended for extended periods of
time.
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/28/2021 it was reported to DCWL that staff left youth unattended in isolation at
the facility. The complainant stated that on 1/5/21 there was an incident where a
resident was acting out and all available staff were called to assist. Staff that were
supervising three youth in isolation, left their position and did not check on the youth
for over two hours. The complainant expressed concern about this lack of
monitoring as one youth in isolation was there due to suicidal behaviors.
DCWL Consultant
On 1/28/21 the assigned DCWL consultant for the facility was contacted. The
consultant reported no prior investigations of this nature. In addition, the consultant
reported some active COVID cases at the facility. Therefore, it was determined that
interviews would be conducted remotely.
Complainant
On 2/1/21 a phone interview was completed with the complainant. The complainant
reported not being present for the incident, but hearing about it from someone else.
The complainant stated that the incident occurred when several staff were pulled
from their assigned locations to assist with a difficult youth. The incident lasted
approximately three hours. During that time, a youth in seclusion, under suicide
watch, was left unchecked for approximately one hour. Two other youth were also in
seclusion for medical reasons and went unchecked. The complainant identified
several staff which were working during that time. However, most were involved in
the other incident at the facility and not aware of what was happening in the
seclusion rooms.
In addition, the complainant reported concerns about how the facility is handling
COVID procedures. The complainant stated that kids do not always wear masks. For
example, during a recent shift, kids were frequently eating and keeping their masks
off. Also, there have been approximately five or six teachers out with COVID or
quarantining. However, none of the students from those classrooms have had to
quarantine. When asked if those students had direct contact with the teacher, the
complainant stated they were in the classroom and that should be enough. The
complainant stated that staff are directed to take youth temperatures but not told
why, and they suspect it is because youth have been exposed. The complainant
feels that staff should be informed of all staff and youth with potential exposure.
Chief Administrator
On 1/29/21 the CA was informed of the investigation. The CA reported being aware
of the situation, stating that a youth was acting out, which required several staff to
assist. The situation lasted a long time as staff attempted to deescalate the youth.
However, while attending to this situation, youth in medical isolation were
3

unattended for approximately 72 minutes The CA reported that some newer staff
were working and missed the 15 minute checks that should have been completed.
The CA acknowledged that this was a long time for youth to be unchecked and it
was not acceptable. The CA has since counseled and retrained staff, and developed
a coverage plan to ensure that this will not happen again. A full internal investigation
was completed and a summary available for DCWL review. The CA stated that he
runs an “above board program” and when mistakes are made, he expects his staff to
be honest, admit it, learn, and move forward.
Regarding the complainant’s COVID concerns, the CA discussed their current
procedures, which align with CDC recommendations. The CA reported that masks
are mandatory for all staff and teachers. Youth are provided masks and encouraged
to wear them, but cannot be forced. There are currently no COVID positive teachers
on-site. The CA sated that students were not automatically quarantined when a
teacher tested positive, as they did not have “close contact” as defined by the CDC.
Teachers are wearing masks, maintaining a six foot or greater distance from
students, and the classrooms are cleaned daily. The facility did have some staff test
positive in 2020. Video was reviewed by the CA to determine which staff and
residents had “close contact” to decide if quarantine was necessary. As the CA was
monitoring these cases and contacts to make determinations, not all of this
information was shared with all staff. Staff not being fully informed of cases with co-
workers, due to privacy reasons, is what likely lead to rumors and speculation.
Lastly, the CA reported feeling that he knew the source of this complaint and
believed it to be a certain staff that has their own ideas about how tracking and
quarantine should work, and is not satisfied with CDC recommendations.
Documents reviewed
 The Center for Disease Control (CDC) recommendations for COVID-19 in
congregate care were reviewed. The agency’s COVID plan appears to be in
compliance with the CDC guidelines. Specific to the complainant’s concern
about quarantining youth from a classroom with a COVID positive teacher:
o For COVID-19, a “close contact” is anyone who was within 6 feet of an
infected person for a total of 15 minutes or more.
As students and teachers are using masks and social distancing, it does not
appear that CDC guidelines support the complainant’s belief that all students
from a classroom should be quarantined when their teacher tests positive.
 The facility does not have a policy outside of the licensing rule regarding
supervision of youth in isolation. Specifically, the facility does not have a
policy about coverage during situations such as the one in this incident.
However, the CA reported staff were aware of the expectation to provide
coverage.
4

 The facility provided a summary of their internal investigation, as the incident
occurred on 1/5/21. The summary concluded the following:
o In person room checks were not completed from 3:01 PM- 4:20 PM
and again from 4:53 PM- 5:16 PM.
o Surveillance video confirmed that facility control room staff manned the
cameras and completed visual checks of an individual in isolation for
suicide/self-harm precautions, and two new youth in isolation for
medical/COVID precautions.
o The paper form, documenting the times of checks, was not completed
by control room staff.
o Upon realizing that checks may not have been completed, Staff 1
checked all three isolated youth and properly documented it.
o All staff have received re-training on proper incident response, room
check procedures and documentation.
o The Chief Administrator noted this was the first incident of this kind at
the facility and he believes their swift and decisive steps to correct the
problem will ensure that it will not happen again.
 The isolation room log was reviewed and found to be missing staff checks as
described in the facility summary.
Foster Care Workers
The foster care workers for the youth in isolation were contacted and reported to be
aware of the incident, and did not have any concerns.
Staff 1
On 3/4/21 Staff 1 was interviewed by phone. Staff 1 reported being present during
the incident. Staff 1 was in a meeting that day when staff called for assistance
regarding a youth at the facility. Staff 1 left the meeting and assisted in the situation.
Staff 1 reported spending a lot of time talking with the youth, trying to deescalate him
to avoid a restraint. Staff 1 stated it took about two hours to achieve their goal and
have the youth back to a regulated emotional state. During this incident, one staff
was called from the control room to switch with Staff 1. Staff 1 then went to the
control room and completed visual checks of the three rooms with youth in isolation.
Staff 1 spoke with all three youth and found no concerns. It was at that time Staff 1
realized that the room check log had not been completed. Staff 1 was unsure if the
prior staff completed checks and forgot to document them, or if the checks were
missed all together. Staff 1 documented on the sheet that the checks were missed
due to the incident in the other unit which required additional staff. Staff 1 noted that
she documented her checks, then called a supervisor to come in from home to
assist. By 6:00 everything was back on track.
Staff 1 stated that as soon as she realized checks were missing, she notified the
Chief Administrator and Family Court Administrator. Administration completed an
internal review and determined that they had to change the COVID procedures, by
bringing all supervisors and clinicians back to the building, rather than continue
5

having them work from home. A review of the incident has since been completed
with all staff. All staff were also retrained on the requirement for checks when
residents are in seclusion.
Staff 1 reported that there is not a specific policy/procedure for coverage during an
incident such as what happened. Generally, the assistant supervisor would
coordinate coverage and make sure everything was taken care of. However, the
assistant supervisor (Staff 2) on duty was new to the facility and still learning
processes. Staff 1 stated that some staff tried to step in and do what they thought
they should do, but they really needed to have supervisor coordination. Staff 1
clarified that staff completed checks via camera during the time staff were not doing
face to face checks, but they did not document the times they were completed. Staff
1 believes that staff have now learned the meaning of, “if it’s not documented, it
didn’t happen”.
Staff 2
On 3/4/21 Staff 2 was interviewed by phone. Staff 2 reported that she was hired in
July 2020 and began the afternoon shift in November 2020. Staff 2 reported being
present during the incident and noted this was only the second time she has been
involved in something like this. Shortly after shift change, around 2:30pm, there was
a call for additional staff to assist with an escalated youth. Several staff went to
assist. Staff 2 reported that the incident lasted approximately two hours.
When asked about checks being completed Staff 2 stated that she has learned from
this incident that she needs to be more direct to ensure everything is covered.
Typically, two staff would be left on the detention side of the facility when additional
staff are called to the residential side. In this incident, remaining staff were unaware
that they were responsible to complete the checks for the youth in isolation. Staff 2
stated that she has learned that she needs to designate this responsibility in the
future.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.10175 Resident confinement room; procedures for use.
(6) During a resident's confinement, visual observations of
the resident shall be made by staff at least every 15
minutes. Each contact shall be logged at the time of the
observation.
6

ANALYSIS: Information gathered from the complainant, chief administrator
and additional staff confirmed that three youth in isolation did
not have documented checks completed every 15 minutes.
While the facility has surveillance footage to show the youth
were being supervised, the visual observations were not
documented as required by this rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status.
